Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 7: Entering Kapilavastu
The yaksa Shakya-shri (Shakya dpal) dwelt in Kapilavastu and the Shakyas honored him as the guardian of their clan.
Manual - English: In a mansion, there is the king along with a retinue. The Buddha takes the form of a boy on the king's lap.  There are brahmins before the king. The king is in a carriage on the road, surrounded by a large retinue. A palanquin with the Buddha and his nanny on it is held up by a large crowd. In a temple, a yakṣa wearing an armor prostrates the Buddha.

Sun of Faith - English: Since custom dictated that the first duty of a Shakya newborn baby, girl or boy, was to pay homage to this local deity, King Shuddhodana made preparations for that rite.
He sent off a carved wooden palanquin, studded with the four kinds of most precious stones, to fetch the Bodhisattva
and waited for him, along with his courtiers and counselors, at the city gates.
At the very instant that the Bodhisattva entered Kapilavastu,

a feeling of humility blew like a soft breeze upon the Shakyas, and worked a deep change of heart in these fierce warriors—who, when all is said and done, were notorious for their crude and cruel character.
Seeing them standing thus hushed and still, one would have sworn that these men had always had the gentlest, most refined manners.
The recalcitrant Shakyas, recognizing that they owed this self-control to the Bodhisattva's power, gave him the epithet Shakyamuni, (Shakya thub pa), the ‘Shakya Tamer’.
When the palanquin neared Shakya-shri's sanctuary, the entire population saw with their own eyes that the statue of the yaksa came alive and walked out of the temple.
Taking the Bodhisattva's feet to its forehead, the statue did a full prostration before the child.
Inscription - English: The yaksa prostrates to the Śākya youth

Sun of Faith - English: “If even Shakya-shri bows down before him, surely this little prince is a god among gods,” murmured the crowd.
Hence ‘god of gods’ was added to the list of his names.
The king put his son in the care of eight wet-nurses and made sure that he received the best care.
He would often dandle the baby on his knees, and feel anxious about what the future might hold in store for him.
One day he had brahmins expert in physiognomy, and sundry other oracle-priests, summoned into his presence to consult them about the prince's prospects.
Most of the sages declared that the child's body clearly showed all thirty-two of the signs of a great being.
They said to the king: "either he will choose family life and become a universal monarch,
or he will abandon the world to live the life of a renunciant and become a tathagata, an arhat who destroys the enemy, ignorance; a perfect buddha.”
Seven days after the birth of the Bodhisattva, his mother passed from this world.
Immediately afterwards she was reborn, with innumerable good qualities, into a family of the Thirty-Three Gods.
Right from his earliest childhood, the Bodhisattva was such that one could never get one's fill of looking at him;
his melodious voice enchanted the ear,
and night and day the fathomless depths of his eyes observed the world around.
The child could already recognize words, written or spoken, and would grasp the essence of their meaning at once.
